head.title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Providence, R.I.; Open Space Deal in Doubt

A SUPERIOR COURT judge's ruling has jeopardized Rhode Island's efforts to buy land for open-space preservation in at least 10 locations.

Judge Alice Gibney's decision came in a controversial case known as Black Point. At issue are 44 acres of waterfront property in Narragansett bought by Ocean Road Partners, a development group, in 1984. It paid $2.4 million for those 44 acres and 23 acres across the street.

The developers plan to build 80 condominium units on the 44-acre site. But environmental groups and advocates of waterfront access protested the development and the state's Attorney General, James E. O'Neill, took their side.
In June 1989, Mr. O'Neill appealed a decision by the state's Coastal Resources Management Council, which had approved the development.

Then, on July 7, 1989, Governor Edward D. DiPrete, condemned the 44 acres, announcing plans to create a waterfront park. The governor's action rendered Mr. O'Neill's appeal moot. Mr. DiPrete was running for re-election at the time.
The state offered the developers $6.4 million for the property, but they filed suit in an appeals process.

The state based its offer on an appraisal that said the highest and best use of the land was one-family house lots. The appraiser who made that determination, Thomas McLaughlin, noted that the condominium market had been souring for some time and by 1989 had all but collapsed.

But an appraiser for the developers, William Coyle Jr., said a market still existed for luxury condominiums in Rhode Island and in their appeal, the developers argued that the value of Black Point was really $15.5 million.
On Oct. 4, Judge Gibney sided with the developers. She ordered the state to pay them $15.5 million, plus interest, bringing the total to over $18 million.

The state has appealed to Rhode Island's Supreme Court, which has agreed to hear the case. If Judge Gibney's decision is upheld, state officials have said the $16 million in the state's open space bond fund would be wiped out.

Pending the outcome of the appeal, 10 open-space projects have been put on hold. "We're really at a standstill," said Judith Benedict, chief of the Division of Planning and Development in the state's Department of Environmental Management.
